title.narrative: Strengthening social capital and reducing tensions between Jordanian host communities and Syrian refugees

description.narrative: Mercy Corps plans to implement a three-year programme focussing on holistic and long-term strategies to address sources of tension and build social cohesion, through empowering community members to peacefully solve community needs resulting in more stable and peaceful communities. Mercy Corps has extensive experience implementing conflict mitigation programming in Jordan – the most recent programming has been under the previous DFID CSSF funded grants (2013-present), in addition to the Netherlands Embassy-funded programme 2014-2018 - ‘Jordanian Host Communities and Syrian Refugees Work Together to Build Peaceful Communities’. We are currently active in 23 at risk communities in Jordan (18 DFID, 5 Dutch), and will continue to expand through this programme into a further 18 communities. We will continue to work towards building stable and peaceful communities by working closely with other actors who are implementing conflict mitigation programmes in Jordan. This will include partnership with the Government of Jordan, in particular the Ministry of Planning & International Cooperation, Ministry of Social Development, Ministry of Water and Irrigation, Ministry of Public Works, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Municipalities, and local government and municipalities. Moreover, Mercy Corps will collaborate with the DFID CSSF funded World Bank programme, particularly with respect to the identification of infrastructure activities, thereby ensuring that both programmes mitigate the duplication of activities and allow for greater coverage of infrastructure interventions.

Overall the intended programme impact is ‘enhanced stability and social cohesion in Jordan’. Programming will be based around the following outcome - ‘Community members are engaged in peaceful approaches to resolving tensions and stressors’. The impact will be achieved through a three-pronged approach: - Output 1: Community members have increased social capital - Output 2: Community support projects promote stability - Output 3: Research and learning strategies are used to inform response to community tensions

humanitarian-scope.narrative: This project relates to the 3RP response plan.
